history.content: No, you need to know Fourier and Laplace transform to do any kind of frequency based control. 16A/B does not cover integral transforms and linear system theory. Unless you self-study those concepts.

children.subject:
This is not the fault of the class. It's like trying to take EE 126 without 70. Yeah, technically it does do a ground-up review of 70, but without it, you're gonna get nothing out of the class. Or even worse, trying to make 127 your first encounter with linear algebra.

People who do all these fancy LA and statistical-based control theory think all engineering math can be figured out on the fly, but pull a surprised Pikachu when a control class expects you to be super familiar with Laplace transforms and regions of convergence.

If you're interested in any type of control or signal processing, 120 is a must. Don't skip it. And 128 is a good class, as long as you have ALL the prereqs.

Yeah of course it's not the fault of the class, but I was trying to be directive with my point to my fellow student; take 120 first, or do a deep prep, because ahead of all the kinda spurious reasoning Cal students use with each other, while you can use geometry and other rough methods to get a clue in the other EE 12X courses, you could not invent some of the concepts in the 128 without doing the reading and homework.

While I do recommend it at as well, Cal students have this post-nihilist look onto their careers. The mantra is that if you don't take x or y course, you can't get a job in your field of choice -- with the ultimate fear being that you'll be stuck in a normal job, with a normal progression, with no real control over your life's trajectory.

No course is going to help you. I've gotten As in courses I cannot remember any of the material for, and failed courses on material that I've been paid to work on, both before and after. Trust/accountability/responsibility or faith alone can help fill the gaps of life's many unknowable, and thereby painful, experiences, but ultimately you have a short amount of time to respond to things, and identifying how instinctive you can get will be far more helpful than EE 128. 

I don't even mean that as a platitude, in industry you're expected to do heavy reading on topics that you don't know enough about, and at a more practical level, while 128's materials are very interesting and applicable to high level work, they are an extreme luxury compared to the basics of 120, or really even getting a fluency in linear algebra, algorithmic design and real analysis. Likewise, no recruiter has ever asked me about the projects I've done in 128, interesting as they are, and instead typically ask about very independent work or deep design work that faced significant, unexpected constraints.

Learning is hard, just as it is rewarding, and I'd encourage a glance through the MIT OCW notes on Signals and Systems, Oppenheimer's edition if you're really raw on the 16A/B material else the more recent one, and just read through the additional notes, and conceptualizations that MIT touches on. Likewise, while it is a bit taboo to my professors, libgen.is has been invaluable to me in terms of sampling textbooks and getting more accurate pacing to my education, allowing me to use classes as a more relaxing, social, perspective-oriented experience than as datapoints on some highly optimized financial function.

"no recruiter has ever asked me about the projects I've done in 128" / "128's materials are very interesting and applicable to high level work, they are an extreme luxury compared to the basics of 120, or really even getting a fluency in linear algebra, algorithmic design and real analysis"

Are you sure you're looking at control jobs? I've also taken Math 110, 104, and CS 170 despite my primary specializations being control and dynamical systems, and they've never come up. I had a recruiter at GM ask me about my 128 and 16B projects, but they've never tested me on control theory per se aside from basic sanity checks like if I knew what BIBO stability was.

This is another that EECS students make. That math is everything. It really isn't. My GM recruiter couldn't have cared less if I knew about clopen sets or if I knew how to prove some random hashing bound. You're an electrical ENGINEER. You're job is to fix that crappy PID your coworker wrote, not to ponder the deep theories of knowledge. Take the right set of classes, and school should be a sufficient toolkit to secure a control engineering job. Your knowledge of transfer functions and state-space control methods will get you far enough. Whatever you don't know, a senior engineer will gladly teach you on the job. No heavy reading required. Leave that stuff to the control theorists and mathematicians.

The 128 textbook covers the 120 material well, as does the excellent MIT OCW series on signals and systems, but having done 128 without 120, I can attest it was one of the most miserable experiences of my life. Everyone in 128 is brilliant, and many are mechanical engineers who are smarter/more focused on the field than the ee side people in the course. Excellent prep work is needed for the class, especially the tedious lab reports. I much preferred courses like EE 126/127/219A for my own inability to conceptualize the ideas of 128

Lightest EE upper div in my opinion. There's 3 midterms, no final, and 6 psets of which you can drop 2. I did take the class quite a while ago though, so things might have changed. But Babak is an excellent professor and it was one of my favorite EECS classes.
thanks! do you think that it would be manageable along with three other techs?

I wouldn't recommend it. Although 120 isn't hard, the concepts do take time to internalize, something that Atom seems to have found out the hard way.

What are you interested in pursuing? If specifically control, I would drop another tech because 120 is the single most important class for you to take. But if you're interested in robotics and other more modern learning-based methods, I would say that 128 isn't actually necessary, and whatever semester you were planning on doing 128 you can just do 120 instead.

Im interested in the latter (learning-based methods) but I want to take 128 just because I am kind of interested in the subject. I did PID tuning for my FRC team back in high school, and I really liked it for some reason.
What is the workload of EE 120 like?

+1

Keep in mind that the prereqs for 221A are Math 110 and EE 120, of which the former is more important but the latter is still recommended. But funnily enough, the Laplace transform comes up in 221A too, since you do discuss the duality of state space and transfer functions. Seems like you can never escape Mr. Laplace.

You can't learn modern without classical imo. 128 isn't necessary, but a lot of robotics and ML people do 120 and 221A, in addition to Math 110.

128 teaches frequency-based control which surprisingly is used in analog circuits more (e.g. compensation of an op-amp). If you want a more modern introduction to control theory, I recommend EE221A+EE222. However, it's always good to know how to interpret the frequency domain if the system is LTI.

history.content: Can you get by in EE 128 with just EECS 16 A/B?
history.subject: Is 120 a strict prereq for 128
